questions.question: Which of the following sorting algorithms always divides the array into two equal halves?

explanations.a: Quick Sort division depends on pivot selection.
explanations.b: Merge Sort always splits the array into two equal or nearly equal halves.
explanations.c: Bubble Sort does not divide the array.

questions.question: In Merge Sort, the array is recursively divided until each subarray contains:

explanations.b: Merge Sort does not stop at three elements.
explanations.c: A single element is considered already sorted.

questions.question: In Quick Sort using the Median of Three approach, the pivot is selected as the median of which elements?

explanations.a: Only one of these represents a good pivot selection strategy.
explanations.b: Median of first, middle, and last helps avoid worst-case partitions.
explanations.c: The algorithm does not choose three middle elements.
explanations.d: Median of three is deterministic, not random.

questions.question: Why does the Median of Three technique improve Quick Sort performance?

answers.b: It avoids selecting extreme pivot values

explanations.a: Recursion depth may reduce indirectly but this is not the main reason.
explanations.b: Choosing a balanced pivot avoids highly unbalanced partitions.

questions.question: After completing the simulation, what can be concluded about Merge Sort and Quick Sort?

answers.a: Both always perform in O(n²) time
answers.b: Merge Sort is in-place and Quick Sort uses extra memory
answers.c: Merge Sort has consistent performance, while Quick Sort depends on pivot selection
answers.d: Quick Sort cannot sort large arrays

explanations.a: Both algorithms are more efficient than O(n²) in most cases.
explanations.b: Merge Sort uses extra memory, not Quick Sort.
explanations.c: Merge Sort performance is consistent, while Quick Sort varies with pivot choice.
explanations.d: Quick Sort can efficiently sort large arrays.
